text:
PAUL MATSUDAIRA: I wanted
to just recap briefly

what we were covering last
week, and then just finish up this discussion
about DNA forensics,

and then we'll go on
to the next topic. So recall that on
Thursday, I just

described to you how information
is encoded in the genome, and that how specific
signatures in the genome

can be used to assess
whether or not you're related to somebody else.

And that's by basically
determining whether or not

in your genome you have a
particular set of alleles at a number of different
locations in your DNA.

And recall that
this figure is just a panel of two gels in which
the different locations

in the genome are assayed by a
PCR-based method in which you

count up the number of
repeats in a DNA sequence. And typically, you would have
two pairs of repeats, one

that you got from
your mother and one that you got from your father. And in some cases if you
see one repeat shown,

that's because in that
instance, those repeats-- the same number of repeats were
inherited from your parents.

So the technology
for DNA forensics is basically to determine
a DNA fingerprint

based on the repeats that are at
different loci in your genome.

And the accuracy of determining
whether your fingerprint, DNA

fingerprint matches
with somebody else is a function of how many
different loci you assay on.

So the name of the game
in the end becomes, how do you size DNA in a way
that's accurate and also turns

out fast? And so I left with
this equation, which basically tells you that
the ability to resolve any two

repeats-- that is, two
lengths of DNA which are different by four bases--

is a function of something
about the gel itself, either the material and how well
it's able to select or interact

between-- with the DNA strands. Also, with the
length of the gel.

The longer a gel has in
contact with a piece of DNA, generally the better you
are able to resolve one

piece of DNA from the other. And then factors which
broaden the band. So either time or diffusion,
which in this term

includes the temperature
at which you do the assay. So if you want to
improve resolution,

then you either change the
gel, you make the gel longer, or you minimize the
effects from either

how you injective the
sample into the gel or how you control
diffusion and broadbanding.

So instead of running
these DNA fragments

on a slab of
acrylamide or agarose or some sort of monolithic,
2D sheet of gel,

the latest configuration in
DNA analysis is based on MEMS.

So MEMS is the anachronism
for Micro Electro Mechanical Systems.

But in this case, instead
of an electronic design,

we have a design for biology. So instead of wires,
you have channels.

Instead of electrons
flowing through wires, you have DNA or protein
flowing down channels.

So the analogy is
directly the same, and the formats are shown here.

So in this chip-- and notice that the scale
here is one centimeter--

you have areas
where you inject-- you load your DNA sample.

These are the lanes in
which the DNA is resolved. There is a waste reservoir.

And somewhere down here, you're
scanning across all eight lanes in this particular configuration
to detect the pieces of DNA

as they come by. So just to give you a
sense of performance,

these are two alleles at
four different loci separated

on a slab gel like the one
you just saw two slides ago. And so you see these two alleles
are well resolved, and so on.

And the time it
took for this band to pass or to resolve on the
gel was approximately a couple

hours. Currently, most DNA testing
is done not on slabs of gels,

but on fine capillaries,
glass capillaries which are filled with gels.

So now we've
basically eliminated all the extraneous gel and now
inject DNA into the capillary,

and the capillary
contains the sample. And so you see, again,
these two same--

or four sets of
alleles now separated in a capillary system. And now the time scale
here is less than an hour.

So there's a
significant improvement in speed or performance
without sacrificing resolution.

Notice that one difference
is that signal to noise is poorer here than
in the slab gel,

but it's still acceptable,
because you could still see the peaks.

In contrast, let's
compare the performance where you inject these same
set of four alleles, loci,

on one of these microchips
where now the time scale's on the order
of a couple minutes.

And you can see
that you can resolve both of these alleles just as
well as you can on a slab gel.

But again, now
the time dimension is minutes rather than hours.

So we've improved
performance in a log scale rather than at a linear scale.

So any time you achieve log
scale gains in performance

for whatever metric you are
measuring, it's a real win.

Now these little peaks
here are actually the DNA ladders that are
co-injected with the sample.

So it gives you
actually a better sense of how well these
microchips can work in resolving the different DNA
fragments than what you might

see in these other systems. So the take-home
message is maybe these microfabricated
formats are
better than current technology. How do they work?

Well, remember I
said that you have channels etched in glass through
standard photolithography

methods. So if you take the Fab course
over in this Data Center,

then you'll-- or in Building
38, then you'll be able to fashion one
of these devices.

You have a well that's
etched in glass. You have a T
configuration in which

you have a separation channel. And across it is designed
a sample loading well

and a waste exit well. So you load your sample-- you fill these
channels with gel.

You load your
sample in this well. You electrophorese or pull
the DNA across that channel

by setting up an electric field. And then when this intersection
is filled with DNA,

you change the polarities
on the ends of the channel, and you pull back the
DNA samples in the wings,

and you launch this plug of DNA
down the separation channel.

And then as the sample
is sized through the gel,

you separate the
different DNA fragments, and then you detect
them as they go past a point at the
end of the channel.

Now I told you something about
factors that affect resolution. This is just a time
lapse movie where

we're imaging the injector if
filled with DNA to the sample. And now we're
switching the polarity,

and we're looking-- this is
fluorescently labeled DNA. And so you're seeing the DNA
as it's being launched down

the separation channel. Notice that the DNA is
getting concentrated as it starts to
initiate its separation.

So this concentration
factor is one of the reasons why
the resolution is much better in this
format, because there's

a change in not only
the polarity on the gel, but it turns out there's
buffer in ion gradients

that are also set up,
which help you resolve these pieces of DNA,
because you concentrate them

in a much narrower band. So that's where you gain on
one part of the equation.

You can run these
gels longer, or you can run these fragments through
longer and longer channels.

we have adequate resolution. So here, length is actually
not as a main consideration.

In fact, the short length
is also an advantage, because the shorter
the length the faster

the run is accomplished. So you can analyze
samples much more quickly, as you saw in these short
microfabricated formats

than in these long slab gels. The other reason is that
because these channels are

only on the order of 100 microns
wide and 40 microns deep, whatever heat is generated
is rapidly dissipated.

So again, that diffusion
broadening parameter is minimized in this format then
compared to the other formats.

And then this just
shows something that we saw in the
other figure, which

is that we can
analyze or multiplex the analysis of several
of these loci at once

in the same injection. So we can resolve all of these
different alleles in these four

different loci. And then by looking
with a scanner at different wavelengths
and injecting samples

that are made with
different color primers, we can then multiplex
additional loci

by including color as
the additional variable or parameter.

OK. So you can see how we
can in one single device improve on the speed of the
DNA detection and resolution

without-- or detection without
sacrificing resolution. And that's basically
the basis for--
that's basically the basis for--

sorry, I can't-- can't talk and
do my PowerPoints at the same time.

And that's the basis
for what we think will be how we're going
to be able to genotype

DNA in the future. Devices based on
the ones I've shown

you are now in test where the
forensics units are bringing

them-- put them into a van,
bringing them out to the field, and are actually testing
DNA samples at the field.

So I think my goal is maybe
I want to be on this TV show

CSI [INAUDIBLE]. Maybe the geeky technician
that does a DNA test.

OK. Any questions about what we just
covered over the last couple days?

If you have questions,
feel free to-- this is a seminar, so
seminars by definition

are not lectures, although
they probably seem like are. So if you really
do have questions,

please feel free to interrupt. This is really to help
give you some background

information about the
basis for bioengineering.

OK. What I want to do
now is to switch to a related topic
about how information

is encoded in the genome. But instead of talking
about information

as in the strictest
sense of sequence of DNA, let's go up one level or
two levels of complexity

in biological structure
and talk about how function is encoded in the genome.

So it's easy to understand
that the genome is a linear sequence of
DNA bases, but then

how do you go from that
information, which is basically a parts list of the different
proteins that are synthesized

in a cell, to including the
instruction set that tells those proteins what to do?

There's no other information
that's encoded in the genome, in other parts of
the genome that says,

this protein carries out
this catalytic reaction. It's all intrinsic to the DNA
subsequence of that protein.

So what we'll do is I'll
cover two important concepts

in understanding
biological structure, which is that there's basically two
ways of building up structure.

Either you do it by chemistry,
i.e. making covalent bonds, or by self-assembly.

And self-assembly is through
interactions by ionic forces

or attractions or repulsions,
van der Waals interactions, and hydrophobic interactions.

And it's those three
sets of interactions that really are responsible
for higher order structure

from the protein level up. And then what I'll
do is I'll show you

an example in
which self-assembly is responsible for generating
force and organizing,

in this case, the genome in
daughter cells during mitosis. And we'll talk a little
bit about the machinery,

the protein machinery that the
cell constructs transiently in order to separate
and partition

of the genome in chromosomes. And then we'll talk about
how that dynamics is

the important target
for anti-cancer drugs. And then we'll go
into a little bit about some aspects of
what we know and think

about anti-tumor drugs. Now there's a
reading if you want

to get a better overview
of this whole area, and it's an excellent review
in Nature Reviews Cancer

by Mary Ann Jordan
and Les Wilson who are at University of Santa Barbara.
OK. Now let's go back. We have genes.

They encode a linear
sequence of DNA. And in the end, what
those genes represent

is the machinery that executes
whatever the information is in the genome to make
a cell and carry out

the functions of a cell. To get to here from
the DNA, we have

to go through an
intermediate step in which the
four-letter DNA code is

translated into a 20-letter
or more amino acid code. And this whole area
encompasses in 701

and in 703 and 705 and
706, all of transcription,

regulation of gene expression,
and protein synthesis.

So in bioengineering, we've
managed to compress that down to one minute or two minutes.

Now this 20-letter code is
just the linear sequence of amino acids,
but it's important

that we understand how the
execution of a function

is carried out by
this machinery. And it's all involved
self-assembly,

as I alluded to earlier. And it has to do with how
that linear string of DNA--

or protein, sorry-- folds up. So again, this is just
basic biological structure.

You have the amino acids here
represented in one-letter code.

It's a one-to-one correspondence
between an amino acid and three bases in
the DNA sequence.

So the codons to amino acid. But what happens next is
that each amino acid has

a particular chemical
characteristic, either hydrophobic
or hydrophilic. It's charged or polar,
non-polar, whatever, OK?

And it's those characteristics
or properties of amino acids

where in their
local environment, they dictate how this
amino acid will interact

with the amino acids around it. And so what you find is
that the linear sequence

of amino acids in a
polypeptide fold locally into a secondary
level of structure.

So sometimes the
amino acids, if they are able to interact
with each other,

will collapse not
into a string-- the string of amino acids
will collapse into a coil.

Or you have a string
of amino acids that will be arranged as
a short, straight sheet

or a short, straight
strand of protein. And so if you look at
the linear sequence

and map onto it in
the protein structure, what are the secondary--

how the protein
sequence is organized in secondary structure,
you have these regions

in which you have local
folds of helices and strands. Now that doesn't tell you
how the protein works.

It just tells you
how the protein is organized at this local level.

Now just as amino acids
interact with each other to give you these local
organized bits of polypeptide,

then it's also true
that these structures,

they have also chemical
characteristics. They interact with the
surrounding amino acids. And you can see how you get
bits or parts of protein folding

up on itself from
these local folds. And in fact, if you look at
the structure of a protein--

and I forgot,
actually, which one this one is-- you can
see that in this case, the structure was determined
by X-ray crystallography.

And you can see that you have
the polypeptide chain starting here.
Meanders around. Let's see. It goes someplace here.

Anyway, comes
around, comes around, comes around in strands. These strands form
part of a sheet.

Then you have a helix
that's rather long. Oh, actually, I
missed out something. The N-terminus goes this way,
this way, this way, this way.

So you have four
strands in a sheet. Then you have a long
helix, and then now you

have these four sheets
or strands, and then this long helix. So there's actually
a two-fold axis

of symmetry described
in the structure. These four strands
and these four strands

are contiguous in space,
but they're actually discontiguous in sequence. But they form a floor over
which is overlaid two helices.

And so you can imagine that
this forms a binding pocket for something else, OK?

So that's just an illustration
of how locally folded elements,

when organized into
three dimensions, collapse into a compact
structure in which they're

connected by loops or turns. There's other parts
of the sequence which have no defined or
apparent regular structure

to them. But that's basically
the elements that give rise to a folded protein.

Proteins can be all helical. They can be all sheet. They can be a
combination of the two.

They can have a lot
of random structure. Depends on the sequence. Depends actually on the
context of the sequence.

Now so the process then is, how
does a polypeptide chain end up

in a native folded structure? And so what I just
described to you was that elements
of local sequence

will fold up into something
that's semi-ordered. So we call that
a molten globule.

Other parts will fold up
sometimes into local folds as well, and that
these will coalesce

into the final native structure. Now a curious thing
is that if you

look at all the permutations
of how a protein can fold up based on the flexibility
of the bonds that

link individual amino acids,
it should take a long time. But obviously, proteins
fold much faster than that,

so there must be pathways
through this complexity and various states of fold
and unfold of proteins

so that the protein typically
folds in a matter of a minute or so in the test tube.

And in a cell, actually
it's even faster than that. So what's responsible
for getting proteins

to fold faster? And generally, you can
understand that as proteins get bigger and
bigger and bigger,

then how do different
parts find each other? Folding must be
intrinsically more difficult

for things that are big
than things that are small. And the answer is that
in the last decade or so,

we found that there are protein
machines called chaperones and chaperonins which
are large macromolecular

structures on the order
of ribosomes or larger, which take the polypeptide
chain as they come out

of the ribosome and bind
to the polypeptide chain, preventing the polypeptide
chain from folding

in an indiscriminate manner
as it's being synthesized so that when the polypeptide
chain is being synthesized,

you get discrete steps
in folding of the protein to a properly folded state.

Or alternatively, how
the protein as it's being synthesized is then
helped in its folding

by these large
macromolecular complexes, and then folded properly
within these protein machines.

So it's the machinery
that the cell has which allows
protein synthesis

to occur in a relatively
error-free manner.

OK. So we've gone now from linear
sequence in amino acids

to local folds. But that's not function, right? If you look at whether or not
this protein can carry out

its function, whether it's an
enzyme to catalyze a chemical reaction or some protein that's
designed to bind something,

it's probably not
going to happen. It's only after the entire
polypeptide chain has folded

in its correct configuration. And so it's in that
three-dimensional context

of the structure
that the protein is able to execute what
it was designed to do.

And so function is
something that's encoded in
three-dimensional structure,

but the three-dimensional
structure in turn is a consequence of the linear
sequence of amino acids.

So you can see then how the DNA
sequence in a protein sequence,

which I referred to as
hardwired instructions, then give rise to these other
higher order functions

that aren't hardwired,
but come out as a consequence of
how those instructions

or how those amino
acids fold up. So a function requires correct
folding and self-assembly

of parts of amino
acids into a protein. OK. Now let's take that
concept of self-assembly--

so these are, again, local
interactions, electrostatic, hydrophobic, van der
Waals interactions--

no covalent bonds made-- and show how higher
order structure is built up within a cell.

OK. So this is the cytoskeleton. Now if you take a mechanics
course, what you'll find out

is that a measure of
stiffness, the material properties of protein is that
a protein has a Young's modulus

on the order of a gigapascal. Now gigapascal to you
may not represent much,

but just think of a
hard, plastic material like polystyrene. That has a Young's modulus of
about a gigapascal as well.

Yet if you push
on a cell, you'll find that its stiffness is
on the order of a kilopascal.

So something, even
though it's made of protein, which are
hard, the structures that those proteins assemble
to is relatively soft.

Now what's the basis for
that material property? Well, let's look at
how structure and then

now property of a material is
built up through self-assembly.

This is an actin filament. It's a polymer of
actin subunits. The subunits here are depicted
as red, white, and blue,

just so that you
could distinguish their positions in the polymer. So it's a linear filament.

Protein subunits tend to add
at one end of the polymer compared to the other.

So it's polarized both in its
structure and in its assembly.

Now the filament itself is
organized into a higher level

structure in the cell. This is an electron micrograph
through the outer region

of a cell. Not much different than this. And what you can
see is that there is a network or a
map of filaments.

Now this can look
disorganized to you, and maybe it is at some level. But if we look in
much more detail

at discrete regions
in this, you see that the filaments are organized
in a very logical way in that

off of one filament is a branch. Off of that filament
is a branch.

Off of that filament
is a branch. So each filament somehow gives
rise to additional filaments

through this branching process. That means that there must
be some other protein which is starting this or nucleating
the assembly of a branch.

And then remember that filaments
grow by adding at the ends. And if we look in
this structure,

we would see that the
ends are certainly here in this structure.

But if we were to look at all
the ends, most of the ends, free ends in this
meshwork actually

lie at the outer
regions of the cell.

Now let's think back to what
I told you about the assembly. Subunits add
preferentially to one end.

And it turns out
that this end is the preferred end for assembly
or addition of subunits.

So imagine what
happens in a cell. You have actin subunits
that are adding

to this end of the filament. Mass is conserved in the
cell, so what must happen?

You would see a translocation
of the entire mass distally in this
picture, or as you're

seeing in this time
lapse movie of a cell, you're seeing mass being
transported centripetally

toward the nucleus of a cell. So what this movie
is showing you is self-assembly
and action where

it's capturing what
we infer is assembly of subunits,
addition of subunits

at the end of these filaments. The entire mass of polymer,
the network of filaments,

are in a sense
treadmilling its way or translocating its way
to this part of the cell.

If mass is conserved,
you balance the equation of addition, and there
must be subtraction,

and you reuse the subunits. So this is, in fact,
how we think cells move.

It turns out that this cell is
stuck to the glass cover slip

by polylysine. The forces of adhesion are
so strong that the cell can't move.

But if you were to let the cell
make and then break adhesions,

then this translocation
of subunits will then change its reference
so that the membrane would then

be pushed forward instead
of the whole mass of polymer being pushed back. So this is on the order
of nanonewtons of force.

Addition of subunits at the end
of each filament end by itself is on the order of a
piconewton of force.

OK, self-assembly. Now let's take that same
example of self-assembly

and let's look at a related
but different system.

Now remember in the second
lecture, I talked about how

the genome-- there's 10 to the 13th
cells in the human body. There's 10 to the 16th total
cells during your lifetime.

That means there must be on
that order of cell divisions in which the entire
contents of your genome

must be faithfully and
accurately replicated and then

distributed to the
daughter cells. That machinery for
distribution of the chromosomes

or the genome from one cell
among two daughter cells is one of the functions
of microtubules.

So again, it's an
element or component of the cytoskeleton
of the cell, and it's

the machinery that's
responsible for doing a certain kind of work. What I'm going to
tell you about is

a little bit about
the biochemistry and the cell biology
of microtubules. It's something, again, you
should have gotten in 701.

Also in 706. Hopefully, in 703 and
705, if you take biology.

And then I'm going
to tell you about how microtubule function
in cell division

can be used as a
wedge or a handle at treating cancers
which are characterized

by uncontrolled cell
division by use of drugs that are specifically designed or
were discovered to act directly

on the ability of microtubules
to generate force. So it's a
mechanics-based problem.
Microtubules.

We just saw what an
actin filament is. It's a linear polymer. Here, a microtubule is
composed of a heterodimer

or the subunit-- the building block
of the polymer is a heterodimer of an alpha
and a beta tubulin protein.

They associate into
a stable heterodimer. And that heterodimer in some
way that I'll show you later

adds in a way that you build
up not a filament, but a tube. So this is a tube
in the true sense.

It has a hollow core
and it has a wall which are composed of the
microtubule or tubulin

subunits. And we define that the subunits
add in a polarized direction,

and they add end on end. The wall of the
microtubules are actually

organized as proto
filaments, which are linear strings of
the tubulin subunit.

Now an important aspect
of microtubule function

has to do with mitosis. So here you see the
genome condensing-- the genome and chromosomes
condensing, organizing

during mitosis in
the metaphase plate. And then now you're going
to see the cells separate or partition the copies of
DNA from one daughter cell

and the other daughter cell. Cell will divide in half
to form the daughter cell. That's basic cell biology.

You must have gotten
that in high school. Now this is an
experiment in which

the microtubules in
the cell are stained with either an antibody
against tubulin,

and the antibody is tagged
with a fluorescent tag so that you can see this in the
light fluorescence microscope,

and in which the DNA or
some component of the DNA is differentially tagged
with a different dye.

In this case, it could be a
dye that stains DNA bases, OK?

So blue is DNA. Green is microtubules. And what you see is
that during the steps

in which the chromosomes
organize into the meta-- and are brought, aligned
into the metaphase plate

and then separated, you
find that the cell has a distribution of microtubules
that seem random in some way.

And then what the
cell does is entirely disassemble its whole cohort
of cytoplasmic microtubules,

and then reassembles them
around the DNA, or in order to organize the DNA.

So you have now a
bipolar structure. The bipolar structure
then assembles

microtubules between them. And then what happens is
that there's a machine.

The microtubules, again,
are dynamic structures. That is, they're continually
adding tubulin subunits

to the ends of
microtubules and taking tubulin subunits off of the
opposite ends of microtubules.

And so you see that you have
a specialized microtubule structure or machine
whose sole function is

to organize the chromosomes and
then distribute the chromosomes to daughter cells.

And so here you have what's
called the mitotic spindle in anaphase where literally
the microtubules are
pulling the chromosomes apart. How is that done? In several ways.

One way involves this concept
of flux or treadmilling of microtubule subunits
through the polymer.

So there's preferential
addition of microtubules at one end of the polymer.

All the microtubules
in the structure are organized in the same way. So they have a polarity that's
uniform in the structure.

So let me explain to you
an experiment in which you

can see this motion of
material going from the center to the ends. This is where the
chromosomes lie.

It's basically this
picture on its side. And then with time,
you see a flux

of material moving to opposite
poles or ends of the structure.

Now why are we able
to see this flux? Well, there was a
technique or method

developed called speckle
microscopy in which you add a tubulin subunit which is
tagged with a fluorescent dye

so you can see the
microtubule in the microscope. However, if the
entire microtubule

was composed of this
tagged tubulin subunit, the whole microtubule
will appear

as a line, a fluorescent line. The trick is-- and if
there's movement or flux

among the subunits,
you would never see it because there
would be nothing to distinguish one part of a
microtubule from the other.

However, if you add the tubulin
subunits that are fluorescently

tagged at a very, very
small relative amount compared to the amount of
protein in the polymer,

then you'd see that the
microtubule will appear speckled if you
were able to see it

as an individual microtubule
in the light microscope. So in contrast,
instead of seeing

a solid or contiguous
line of fluorescence, you would see a discontinuous--

maybe a line in fluorescence. Maybe you might not even
be able to distinguish it

as one microtubule because
the labeling is so low.

However, imagine-- so that's
why you see these speckles here instead of the lines of
microtubules that we saw,
for instance, in this picture.

In this picture, we see the
microtubules as linear objects. So here's the experiment.

You just take a time
lapse movie like this. And for each frame,
you physically box

out one segment,
which we show here

as the chromosomes in
green and the speckles that happen to be in that box.

Now what you see in
the subsequence time frames is that the chromosomes
basically stay in place.

They're not moving
in that interval. But notice what happens here.

You see lines or traces of flux
in which this speckle appears

to be moving with time
in a direction that's opposite to the position
of the chromosome.

That is, you have a
biradial flow of material from the chromosomes toward the
poles of the mitotic apparatus.

What that's telling you is that
material is being added here

and that that fiduciary
marker on the microtubule is now moving out,
implying that there's

new material that's being
added at the chromosomes during metaphase. So you see this as a flux or
movement of material outward

toward the pole at metaphase. So because there's a flux, it
means that it's doing work.

But in this case, the
work is unproductive, because the chromosomes
are staying in place.

It's as if you have a car engine
in which the engine is revving up, but the problem is that you
don't have the clutch engaged.

Now what happens
at the next stage is that the cell
actually asks questions at a biochemical level and
says, are all the chromosomes

aligned? Are all the chromosomes
attach to microtubules? Is everything else sort of OK?

If so, yes, let's get started. And what happens
is that there are proteins that keep the sister
chromatids or the pairs

of chromosomes
physically together, and those bonds between
those proteins break.

These proteins are called
cohesins, and they break. And if you take 703 from
Professor Orr-Weaver,

her lab studies these
cohesin proteins. So if the bonds between
the chromosomes break,

then obviously any force
directed on the chromosomes is now transduced into the
movement of the chromosomes.

That's one part of it. You have to have the
chromosomes separating, but also you have to get
the flux of incorporation

of microtubules
at the chromosomes to be translated
into a pulling force.

And that requires another set of
proteins, which are designed-- that are on the chromosomes
to actually latch on

to the end of a
chromosome, and then thereby being transported
out as mitosis continues.

OK. So that's how you get
chromosomes to the end. Once they're to the opposite
poles, cells divide in half.

You have two daughters cells. Mitosis is finished. Now cancer, if you
think about it,

is basically a problem in
unregulated cell division. Tumors grow because cells
divide when they're not

supposed to in places
that they're not supposed to at times when
they're not supposed to.

So this whole process
of cellular division somehow goes awry. Also, the cells move
to different places

in the body and start
tumors at different sites. So this is just a
picture of some organ.

Probably liver. And you can see these
different tumor masses in it. And at the histological level
in the light microscope,

you can distinguish these blocks
or aggregates of tumor cells from normal cells.

So anti-cancer treatments are
designed to kill tumor cells

differentially-- you don't
want to kill normal cells-- or somehow control of
the properties of a tumor

cell relative to a normal cell. A tumor cell is not that much
different than a normal cell.

It's on the order of a few
mutations in the genome that's being expressed.

So where does
microtubules come in? The seminal observation was
about 25 or 35 years ago when

Susan Horwitz's group discovered
that a drug or a chemical

compound that the National
Cancer Institute had isolated

and found to have anti-cancer
properties or anti-tumor properties basically--

and the structure
is shown here-- had an unusual property of
causing the microtubules

in the cell not to break down. So you can think of, how
do you disrupt mitosis?

Well, if you can't form the
structure in the first place, then obviously the
cell can't divide.

However, that's
not what happened. If you look at these
micrographs where, again, you have chromosomes in
blue and microtubules

in this case in red,
you see that the cell is able to form microtubules. But in the presence
of Taxol, you

have committed the microtubules
to assemble in such a way that you have
disorganized the DNA.

So here you have chromosomes
at the poles instead of all at the metaphase plate. You have this aberrant kind
of structure, and so on.

So there's unregulated
assembly of microtubules.

And the important property
is that what they found

was that this Taxol binds and
stabilizes the microtubules.

So you prevent the
dynamics from occurring. If the microtubules
aren't dynamic, then

from a mechanics point of
view, it can't generate force. If it can't generate
force, then there's

nothing to separate
the microtubule-- or the chromosomes. So this is a mechanic--
you can think

of this as a chemically
based problem, but it really is, in fact,
a mechanics-based problem.

I.e., why you're a bioengineer. Now what is it of
microtubule dynamics?

We saw it in the
time lapse movie from the speckle microscopy. The basis for dynamics
is that microtubules,

like actin filaments, are
polar in their structure. So one end is chemically
different than the other end.

Subunits add preferentially
to one end or the other. So in this case, the preferred
end of a microtubule.

If we backtrack just one
second, if we mark a set of microtubules-- just say
we can tag them with a dye

or something-- and then we watch how a
microtubule grows, what we'll see is that on
average, one end will

grow longer than the other end. But also notice that
there's a dynamic

even to the assembly of
microtubules in that they go through these cycles of
assembly and disassembly,

so that if you trace any
one microtubule length, you'll see that it'll fluctuate
over a large range of lengths

with time, because it's
adding and subtracting subunits at both ends.

Both ends are in dynamic
flux, but one end is dominating over the other.
So microtubules go like this. Well, actually, like this.

Now what happens
when you add Taxol? Taxol binds to the
walls of the microtubule and somehow prevents this
dynamic disassembly reaction

from happening. So it's as if the Taxol
binds and glues the subunits together. What you see is that
as a microtubule,

Sometimes it may grow shorter. But it doesn't have the
dynamic characteristic like a native
microtubule would have.

So Taxol works at
the molecular level by affecting how a
microtubule breaks down.
How does that work? I gave you the clue before.

This is a diagram of the
wall of a microtubule. Taxol actually
binds on the inside.

And it, in fact, is binding
at a site in which it affects

not only the microtubules
bound-- or tubulin subunit that it's bound to,
but also its neighbors.

You can look at it and
you can actually envisage why it prevents disassembly. Right now in this
position, it seems

as though it's acting to bind
these subunits all together.

So that's the interpretation
of how Taxol works. These happen to be the
locations of where other drugs,

anti-cancer drugs, work
that are also targets-- whose targets are microtubules.

Colchicine is a
compound which causes microtubules to break down
instead of microtubules

to be stable. And at very low
concentrations, it also prevents the microtubule
from being dynamic.

There's a third drug
called Vinblastine. It's actually one of the
earliest ones that were used, which binds solely to
the ends of microtubules.

Again, it affects the
dynamics in much the same way that Taxol does.

OK. So microtubules are
the main structure

of the protein machine
that separates chromosomes. From the dynamics, you

that it's also part of
the structure that's responsible for generating the

because if you can

wedge into controlling

review of the

act on microtubules

and where they are in

It's a very complex molecule. It's extracted from the
yew tree, a Pacific yew

tree, which is not a very
good source for the material. So the routes for making Taxol
is through chemical synthesis.

You can start from
the base molecules and build up the
synthesis, and that's

like a 50-step synthesis. Or you can identify a naturally
occurring intermediate

which you can use as a base,
which in a four-step process you can then build up Taxol.

And that's the
economically favored route for synthesizing Taxol.

As a bioengineer, you

in Taxol synthesis pathway

and having them

And that's actually a topic for

has to do with making Taxol.

Taxol is insoluble, so you
have to inject it with an oil

to keep the solubility up. So you can engineer

have better solubility

Now it's used to
control cell division. Let's think about stents
and the operation of stents.

When you go in and you basically
scrub the wall of a blood vessel, you put in place
this metal scaffold,

which is designed to
keep the wall open. However, one common
problem is that the cells

in the lining of
this wall overgrow that scaffold and gradually
grow back and block that vessel.

So that's a bad thing. I'll just alert you
too that Taxol--

or one new development
in stents is to then coat them with drugs
that are designed to knock down

or to slow down cell
growth around that stent. And of course, Taxol is
one of those drugs that

is embedded in a polymer that's
designed to slowly release Taxol so that you do knock down
or keep down cell growth, which

is called restenosis. So that's an example where we
understand the basic biology,

we understand the
technological applications, and a little bit of how
engineering in the chemistry

will get you from
one to the other. Think about other examples, how
chemistry or engineering can

help us with relating
Taxol with cancer.
